intro: Erigeron petrophilus var. petrophilus, commonly known as the rock eryngo, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its gray-green, hairy foliage and clusters of small, blue to purple composite flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in mountainous regions. It has a compact growth habit and is often found in open, sunny habitats. Its flowering period occurs in late summer to early fall, attracting various pollinators.
